setup.question: What did Zen think of the plan the royal father and daughter hatched?
answers: He was aware of the plan unfolding the entire time because of his all-knowing
He was unhappy when they told him

Text.text: Both seem possible.
Central to life and existence on the planet of Uxen is their God, named Zen, also known as
--"omnipotent" is pretty self-explanatory as is the repeated use of
and

. Though he does occasionally have to work and think in order to keep up with the demands of being an omnipotent and thus omnisicent being, he has long ago mastered the art of keeping track of everything, including the futile plans of the King and his daughter, the Princess.
Zen is god of planet of Uxen while omnipotent his powers work in interesting ways, He has around
which he uses to do his subjects bidding. Despite this he still has opinions about what goes on in his subjects lives.

<- example of him viewing one of the researchers who came to visit his plan. Then the royal daughter and her father hatch a plan to follow the earthlings to earth to observe their nuclear research. Unhappy that he has to work more
the daughter volunteers Zen to help him
quote limit reached but can provide more

A: The point about omnipotence is compelling, but I'd like to hear your thoughts on two points: first, what if this is irony? Second: this is somewhat circumstantial. Can you provide any direct evidence of him knowing "the plan" specifically? Is there a point when father/daughter tell him, even if he already knows?

B: None of this is really relevant; maybe he was unhappy because he already knew? Can you provide clarity about when he was told? And, any counter to A's claim of omniscience?

B having no evidence for the actual "unhappiness" or lack of knowing about the scheme/plan should end the round. I mean the only use of unhappy isn't even in quotes in their speech its regular text - conjecture effectively. the princess admits she
and Zen roasts them
first of all he is not really aware of the plan because he is literally on his day off when they begin to hatch it

context for A's quotes, The princess is ordered to make food for the earthmen and calls on Zen to help cook for her, he is already pissed cause he is working on his day off, and as his prime minister says
not to mention when she summons him to cook the food the
Not sure what A was trying to say with their last two quotes but they clearly cant back up their argument hope this helped

Revising in B's favor. A, you didn't provide any of the evidence or argumentation I requested. Can you give evidence of him knowing the plan ahead of time? B also gives evidence of Zen being unhappy and disagreeable.
B: When is Zen actually told the plan? And...what is the plan? Like what are the princess and her father doing? Is it the cooking thing?

Plan: the Princess and the King want to see/use the Earth scientists' research in secret because they want to use their work to free the planet from Zen, cuz the King misses being the highest power.

Zen is all-knowing because

. This quote's huge because it also indicates that on his day off he's still working so you should reject all attempts by B to claim the day off matters. 

The reason A is honest - this whole story is Zen listening to the plan and the characters while invisible. Here he hears the princess:
. This whole time hes followed them.
when the earthmen come the princess and her father come up with a plan
I see that A has provided the quote for their plan however they're again lying, Zen does not hear their plan,
this is the sentence after and all the way until multiple paragraphs later does the princess say
and here is where he groans to himself (look at quotes to help) -> yeah he's omniscient but he only hears things when called! which is why on his day off he was annoyed to be summoned and tuned out
continuation of quot

Okay I think we're getting somewhere now. There looks to be direct clash on the following:
- Did Zen hear the plan or not?
- Does Zen hear things only when called?

B: why do they ever tell Zen the plan? If it's to free the planet from him, why would they tell him?

B says i'm lying with zero proof. this round should be over. the whole story is told from Zen's perspective (its 3rd person but still).
if Zen didn't hear about the plan then we wouldn't hear about the plan because we only exist through Zen's eyes. thats the context of the evidence - the story begins with
(the line is at 50 cuz the v. beginning is a transcriber's note), and we never leave his eyes. proof its his perspective (

).
 Zen knows the plan's a threat to his power:

.

lastly - no scene where they tell Zen about the plan, 0 evidence. round's over.

the ev of him finding out the plan has been presented all round -> he's omnipotent but only is when he is summoned (this is why he can hear things about him from far away). its his day off tho so hes not trying to know about everything (see ev)

another quote of ppl talking about zen without him knowing, if he was aware of things all the time then why do they summon him, he should just show up. 

A provides quotes in their last speech that are out of context which lowk feels like they're lying
Ending for A. B didn't really answer my last question, and the preponderance of evidence seems in A's favor.

answers.reason for outcome: According to the judge its cause i didn't answer their last question which i think is true however since every quote talks about how Zen is omniscient I feel like i lost the debate then and there at the beginning because the judge can kind of put two and two together and since there is no direct quote explaining that Zen finds out so much of my evidence focused on semantics and reasoning instead of evidence which is always a dead give away for a judge
